column2: Though we scarcely expected it, our secret remained in our own keeping alone.

column2: It was the end of November, all the verdure of the garden had disappeared, the trees were nothing more than skeletons with their long bony arms, and the dead leaves sounded on the gravel under my feet. column2: I fancied continually that I saw the figure of the Corsican between the branches.

column2: I examined the thicket with my dark lantern; it was empty.
column3: I examined the thicket with my dark lantern; it was empty.

column2: I looked carefully around; I was indeed alone,--no noise disturbed the silence but the owl, whose piercing cry seemed to be calling up the phantoms of the night. I tied my lantern to a forked branch I had noticed a year before at the precise spot where I stopped to dig the hole.

column3: Still one place where the grass was thin attracted my attention; it evidently was there I had turned up the ground.

column2: The hour, then, for which I had been waiting during the last year had at length arrived.
column3: The hour, then, for which I had been waiting during the last year had at length arrived.

column2: How I worked, how I hoped, how I struck every piece of turf, thinking to find some resistance to my spade!
column3: How I worked, how I hoped, how I struck every piece of turf, thinking to find some resistance to my spade!

column2: But no, I found nothing, though I had made a hole twice as large as the first.

column2: I thought I had been deceived--had mistaken the spot.

column2: Something more terrible, more fatal, more alarming for us--the child was, perhaps, alive, and the assassin may have saved it!
column3: Something more terrible, more fatal, more alarming for us-the child was, perhaps, alive, and the assassin may have saved it!

column2: Madame Danglars uttered a piercing cry, and, seizing Villefort's hands, exclaimed, "My child was alive?" said she; "you buried my child alive? You were not certain my child was dead, and you buried it?
column3: Madame Danglars uttered a piercing cry, and, seizing Villefort's hands, exclaimed, "My child was alive?" said she; "you buried my child alive? You were not certain my child was dead, and you buried it?

column2: Ah"--

column3: Madame Danglars had risen, and stood before the procureur, whose hands she wrung in her feeble grasp.

column2: I know not; I merely suppose so, as I might suppose anything else, replied Villefort with a look so fixed, it indicated that his powerful mind was on the verge of despair and madness.

column2: Ah, my child, my poor child! cried the baroness, falling on her chair, and stifling her sobs in her handkerchief.

column2: Villefort, becoming somewhat reassured, perceived that to avert the maternal storm gathering over his head, he must inspire Madame Danglars with the terror he felt.

column2: You understand, then, that if it were so, said he, rising in his turn, and approaching the baroness, to speak to her in a lower tone, "we are lost.

column2: This child lives, and some one knows it lives--some one is in possession of our secret; and since Monte Cristo speaks before us of a child disinterred, when that child could not be found, it is he who is in possession of our secret."
column3: This child lives, and some one knows it lives-some one is in possession of our secret; and since Monte Cristo speaks before us of a child disinterred, when that child could not be found, it is he who is in possession of our secret."

column3: Just God, avenging God! murmured Madame Danglars.

column2: But the child--the child, sir? repeated the agitated mother.
column3: But the child-the child, sir? repeated the agitated mother.

column2: How I have searched for him, replied Villefort, wringing his hands; "how I have called him in my long sleepless nights; how I have longed for royal wealth to purchase a million of secrets from a million of men, and to find mine among them!

column3: A child encumbers a fugitive; perhaps, on perceiving it was still alive, he had thrown it into the river."

column2: Impossible! cried Madame Danglars: "a man may murder another out of revenge, but he would not deliberately drown a child."
column3: Impossible! cried Madame Danglars: "a man may murder another out of revenge, but he would not deliberately drown a child."
